title: Does the United States have more gun deaths in one day than other countries in one year?
text: A week before the anniversary of the mass shooting at Mariory Stoneman Douglas High School, the Judicial Committee of the House of Representatives held its first hearing on armed violence nearly a decade ago. The President of the Commission of the United States Republic of America, Gerold Nadler, D-N.Y., opened the hearing with a merciless statement: "Every day in America, on average, 34 people are killed with a firearm, and more than 183 people are injured in an attack." Nadler warned against the proliferation of firearms violence in the United States compared to other industrialized countries. "But while no other country in the industrialized world will tolerate such statistics - in fact, in most of those countries firearms deaths barely break three figures a year - in the United States, they are accepted as a dark reality," Nadler said. "In comparison, in 2011, for example, the United Kingdom had 146 deaths due to armed violence; Denmark 71; Portugal 142; and Japan 30. But last year, in the United States, about 40,000." The Judicial Committee of the Chamber of Deputies approved the Human Rights Act 8, the bi-party background check, by a vote of 23 to 15 in February, in preparation for a full vote by the Council. When he said "last year," he probably referred to the number of gun deaths in 2017, the last year for which data were available, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In that year, there were 39,773 firearms-related deaths. This number absorbs deaths resulting from suicide, murder, unintentional and unspecified deaths, as well as deaths resulting from law enforcement. Experts noted that Nadler highlighted a small sample, leaving developed countries with an increase in the number of deaths caused by firearms. For example, France experienced about 2,330 firearms-related deaths in 2016, while Germany recorded 1,220 firearms deaths that year, according to a study by researchers at the Institute of Health Measurement and Assessment at Washington University on global firearms deaths, 1990-2016. It is also important to consider differences in population size when making comparisons with other countries. Philip Cook, a leading arms researcher and an honorary professor of public policy from Duke University, said: "The point he makes, however, is that the United States has a far greater number of weapons deaths than any other industrialized country, and its per capita is much greater than any other industrialized State - the right point." Although there is no uniform definition of industrialized countries, a study published in 2016 in the American Journal of Medicine compared total firearms mortality rates per 100,000 people in high-income OECD countries in 2010. The figures cited by Nadler were quite accurate in the corresponding years, but his claim lacked some context.
